text: Hello students, a very warm welcome. I am Bharat, your companion for the one and only School Plus
program at Akash. In the previous lecture, we have discussed about the various types of cells
which are present in blood, RBC, WBC, platelets. We discussed about their characteristics and we
also discussed about their functions. We had a discussion regarding the type of blood groups
and the RH factor. We also discussed about the blood clotting. In today's lecture, we will take
the lesson forward and we will talk about circulatory pathways. We will have a broad
discussion on the structure of human heart, the cardiac cycle and the ECG. To start with,
first we will discuss about the circulatory pathways. As if you remember, we have discussed
in the chapter of Kingdom Animalia that there are two different types of circulatory systems
which are present in animals and they are open circulatory system and closed circulatory system.
Open circulatory system is a kind of a system in which the blood flows through open spaces or
the sinuses of the body. So, in case of open circulatory system, blood is pumped by heart,
then it passes through large vessels and then it moves into open spaces or body cavities which
are called a sinuses. And this kind of circulatory system is present in orthopods, molluscs,
except cephalopods like octopus, hemicordates and tunicates. Whereas, the closed circulatory system
like we have. In case of closed circulatory system like over here you can see in this picture,
the blood is pumped by the heart which always flow in closed path means there are defined vessels,
there are defined paths that is arteries, veins and capillaries in which the blood flows. It does not
flow in open spaces of the body. And this kind of system is present in annelids and caudates.
And this closed circulatory system is considered to be more advantageous. Why? Because the flow of blood
can be precisely regulated in this kind of system. Now, talking about the structure of heart and we'll
first have a discussion on the number of chambers which are present in hearts of different animals.
So, to start with the fishes. In case of fishes, there is two chambered heart. There is one atrium
and there is one ventricle. So, the heart pumps deoxygenated blood and which is then oxygenated
by the gills. And once the blood is oxygenated by the gills, it is taken to the all parts of the body
and from where the deoxygenated blood is again brought back to the heart. So, heart is actually
pumping deoxygenated blood. From heart, it moves to gills. In gills, it is getting oxygenated and from gills,
it is moving to body parts, transferring oxygen, getting deoxygenating also simultaneously
and then the blood is returning to heart. The second is amphibians and reptiles. In case of amphibian
and reptiles, there are three chambers in the heart. There are two atria and there is one ventricle.
As you can see in this both of structures. So, in these organisms, the left atrium receives oxygenated
blood from the lungs or the gills or the skin whereas the right atrium receives the deoxygenated
blood from the body parts. As you can see in both these structures, amphibians has three chambered heart
whereas in case of reptiles, they also have three chambered heart but there is a development of a septum
which is still incomplete between the two ventricles. There is a development of a wall if you can see
but it is still incomplete. So, there is a mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood
in amphibians and reptiles and this kind of circulation is called as incomplete double circulation.
In fishes, we had single circulation but in these that is amphibians and reptiles,
there is an incomplete double circulation. In contrast to amphibians and reptiles,
the birds and mammals have double circulation means complete double circulation. There is no mixing
of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood because they have four chambered heart. As you can see
the four chambered and there is a septum which is present. The septum has become complete
between the left side and the right side. So, they have two atria and two ventricles. Ventricles pump
blood without any kind of mixing. Two separate circulatory pathways are present here. So, the animals
are said to be having a double circulation. Now talking about the internal structure of human heart.
So, let us take it. So, this is a representation of human heart where the heart is mesodermally or derived
organ. We know that there are three different types of germinal layers which are present during the
embryonic development that is ectoderm, mesoderm and the endoderm. So, heart is derived from mesodermal
cells. It is situated in the thoracic cavity means in the rib cage and is present in between the two
lungs and slightly tilted towards the left. As you can see the tilt in this diagram also.
And the size of human heart is roughly around the size of clenched fist, mutthi. It is protected by
a double-walled membranous bag which is called as pericardium. There are two layers which are covering
this called as pericardium and between the two pericardium we have pericardial fluid which is acting
as a shock absorber. Now discussing about the structure of human heart. There are two relatively
small upper chambers which are called as atria and two larger lower chambers which are called as ventricles.
As you can see there is a left and right atrium and left and right ventricles. The size of ventricles
is larger in comparison to atrium as you can see in this picture also. Now talking further here is the
pulmonary artery. The artery is something which is carrying blood to body parts and it is connected to
right ventricle. And this pulmonary artery is carrying blood to which body part? Lungs. The details of how
the oxygenated and deoxygenated blood is pumped by heart to various parts of the body we will have a
discussion later on in double circulation. Then we have this pulmonary vein. The pulmonary vein is actually
bringing blood from lungs and it is draining into left atrium. Then you have aorta. Aorta is the largest artery
in human body and it is receiving blood from left ventricle or you can say the left ventricle is pumping blood
into iota and the iota is carrying it to different body parts. Then you have vena cava. The vena cava is
bringing blood from body to heart and it is draining into right atrium. Here is the apex of the heart which is
slightly tilted as i told you. Here is the caudate tendon. Now here is the diagram where again you can see
different type of chambers the right and left atrium, left ventricle, right ventricle. You have to remember
your right is left here means it is mirrored. Now talking about the various septa or the septum which
is present between the different chambers. The septum are nothing but the walls. The first is the
inter atrial septum. Inter atrial septum means the septum between the two atria. So this is thin muscular
wall which separates the right and the left atria as you can see this wall. As you can see this wall is
present between right atrium and left atrium. So this is called as inter atrial septum. Then you have
inter ventricular septum. It is thick walled and it separates the left and the right ventricle. As you
can see here is the inter ventricular septum which is separating right and left ventricle and it is quite
thick. The walls of the ventricle are thick because they have to pump blood to the body. Throughout the
body they have to pump but this is not the necessity with atrium. Why? Because they are just receiving the
blood and they have to just pump into the next chamber which is ventricle. But ventricle they have
to pump throughout the body. So their walls have to be thick so as to sustain or to provide that much
pressure. Now talking about atrio ventricular septum. Atrio ventricular septum is the wall between the
atrium and the ventricle of the same side. These are separated by thick fibrous tissue. So here is
atrio ventricular septum means the wall between atrium and ventricle and there is a gap between you can
see and they are nothing but valves through which the blood will move from one chamber to another.
So you can see valves. So actually atrio ventricular septum has valves. Now talking about these valves only.
What is the purpose of these valves and how they are being named and where they are present in heart.
So here is the structure of heart once again. First talking about atrio ventricular valves
means AV valve means they are present between atrium and ventricle. So they are actually regulating
the flow of blood from atrium to ventricle. Now each of atrio ventricular septa are provided with an
opening through which the two chambers of the same side are connected. As I already told you
on the same side atria and ventricle are connected through these gaps which are regulated by valves.
The first type of AV valve is called tricuspid valve. It is the opening between the right atrium
and the right ventricle and it is made up of three muscular flaps. Here is the tricuspid valve
you can see. So where it is present between the right atrium and the right ventricle.
Then we have another valve which is called as mitral valve or the bicuspid valve.
So it guards the opening between the left atrium and the left ventricle.
Here it is you can see the mitral valve. So it is connecting left side means the left atrium
and the left ventricle. Taking it further now we will talk about the semilunar valves.
So semilunar valves are actually present between the ventricles and arteries.
So they are regulating the flow of blood from ventricles into the arteries.
So it is opening of the right and left ventricles into the pulmonary artery
and the aorta respectively. So the first one is the pulmonary valve.
So pulmonary valve is a opening between the right ventricle and pulmonary artery.
pulmonary as you can see here is the pulmonary valve. It is present between the right ventricle
and this pulmonary artery. Then the another one is the aortic valve. Here it is. The aortic valve
is regulating the flow of blood from left ventricle into the aorta, into the aorta.
So these valves are actually being provided to regulate the flow of blood so that the blood
flows only in one direction. It prevents any kind of back flow which can happen.
Now taking it forward and now we will discuss about the distribution of special type of musculature
which is present in human heart which is actually responsible for the conduction of
nerve signals throughout the heart. Heart as we have discussed heart is myogenic in nature.
Heart can produce those electrical signals for the contraction of its musculature on its own.
It does not depend upon central nervous system for sending those signals. So let us discuss about that.
You can see here at the top most corner of the right atrium there is a specialized tissue
and this is called as SA node. It is a specialized cardiac musculature and this nodal tissue is
distributed in the heart. The patch of this tissue is present in the right upper corner as I already told
you which is called as SA node. There is another mass of this tissue which is present on the lower left
corner of the right atrium. Here lower left corner of the right atrium. Remember they are present within the
walls. They are musculature. They are not present inside the heart. They are present in the walls.
Obviously it is a limitation to show here. Here is the AV node. Now this specialized musculature
is called as AV node or the AVN.
So I am repeating this thing once again. The special musculature is distributed throughout the
heart which is responsible for the conduction of nerve impulse within the heart.
And the specialized nodal tissue is SA node which is present towards the top of the right atrium.
Whereas the another one is AVN which is present on the lower left corner of the right atrium.
Then there is a bundle of nodal fibers which are called as AV bundles.
Actually they continue from AV node. From AV node there are nodal fibers which are emerging.
And these fibers which are emerging from AV node are called as AV bundle together and thus
they are also called as the bundle of IS. So here is the nodal fibers you can see.
They are emerging from AV node then moving into the septa between the ventricles.
And this is called as the left bundle because there are two bundles which are present.
Left bundle and the right bundle. And then these immediately branches into minute fibers
which move into the ventricles which move into the ventricular musculature. And this is called as
Purkinsey fibers. So from AV node this specialized musculature is emerging called as the AV bundle.
AV bundle divides into two. Left bundle and the right bundle. They immediately move into the walls
of the ventricles where they divide into minute musculatures specialized ones and they are called
Purkinsey fibers. These nodal musculature has the ability to generate action potentials without any external
stimulus. That means they are auto excitable. As I told you earlier also the heart generates on its own
the action potential. The central nervous system is not sending signal to heart. Although it is regulating
the activities but as such it is not sending the signals for heart to pump. The number of action
potentials that could be generated in a minute vary at different parts of the nodal system.
The SAN the SA node this is most important. It produces maximum number of action potential
around 70 to 75 per minute and is responsible for initiating and maintaining the rhythmic contraction
of the heart. So therefore this is called as the pacemaker of the heart. So the rhythmic contractions
and relaxations which are happening in the heart. The signal for that is generating within the heart.
Where? In the SA node. And from SA node this signal will move further. It will reach AV node and then
throughout the heart. Now we will understand the same thing with the help of this diagram. Here is the
Sinoatrial node. From Sinoatrial node the signal reaches AV node. Here is the AV node. Then the AV node
give rise to HIS bundle. See then HIS bundle is dividing into two. Left bundle and the right bundle as you can see.
And these left bundle are further moving into the septa of ventricle and then moving into entire walls of ventricle.
Where they are dividing into minute fibers and they are being called as Purkinsey fiber as you can see.
Now discussing about cardiac cycle. The sequential events in the heart which is cyclically repeated
is called as the cardiac cycle and it consists of contractions which is called as systole and
the relaxations which is called as the diastole. So they happen in a very systematic cyclical manner.
And this entire cycle of systole and diastole which happens in the different chambers of human art is called
as the cardiac cycle. Now to start with the cardiac cycle. Both atrium and the ventricles are in the relaxed state.
And this relaxed state will be called as joint diastole. Why we are calling it as a joint diastole?
Because atrium as well as the ventricles they are relaxed. And the blood is freely entering into the atrium.
And at this moment our tricuspid valve and the mitral valve which we also called as the AV valves together
they are open. Here you can see in this picture. This tricuspid valve and here you can see the mitral valve.
They are open and the blood is freely flowing in. But you have to remember that at this moment this
pulmonary valve and the aortic valve they are closed. So the blood is getting filled into the ventricle
via atrium. Now what will happen the SA node that specialized musculature or the nodal center
now that will generate the action potential. SA node which we already discussed is called as the pacemaker.
It is generating action potential. This action potential will move into the walls of the atria
and it will cause the contraction of atria and it will cause the contraction of atrium. Once the contraction
of atrium will happen the blood volume into the ventricle will increase by almost 30 percent.
So what is contracting at this time? Atria are contracting but ventricles are relaxed. So this
stage is called as the atrial systole and
as the volume of ventricle increases by this time the action potential which was generated in SA node
has reached AV node. From AV node it has moved into AV bundles and through that bundles of his and entire
musculature of ventricle. So the signal has reached in the walls of ventricle. So ventricles will now undergo
contraction and we will call it as ventricular systole. So here comes the ventricular systole
and by this time atrium are relaxed. So the blood is now into the ventricles and ventricles have started pumping.
And due to this pumping and increase of pressure what will happen? The tricuspid valve as you can see here
and the bicuspid valve the mitral valve as you can see they have become closed because there is an attempted
backflow in the atrium. So they have closed. So any backflow back into the atrium is now prevented.
But simultaneously what will happen? This pressure will cause the opening of
pulmonary valve as you can see here and the aortic valve. The aortic valve the pulmonary valve
they have become open because of this pressure generated in ventricle. So these valves are called
semirunar valves. So semirunar valves are open and blood is now moving into the arteries.
From each respective side they are moving into aorta and the pulmonary artery. Now what will happen?
As the blood flows into arteries the pressure will decrease. Where it decreases? In ventricles.
Now as the pressure decreases in ventricles what will happen? Our bicuspid valve and tricuspid valve
they will become open again and blood will start entering into them again.
Now this completes the entire cycle of contractions and relaxation. So now again ventricles are relaxed.
Atrium were already relaxed. So once again it comes the joint diastole.
Now moving forward we will discuss about cardiac output. We know that the heart beats 72 times per minute
and that many cardiac cycles are performed per minute. Now therefore the duration of cardiac cycle
is roughly around 0.8 seconds. Now during a cardiac cycle each ventricle pumps out approximately 70 ml of blood
which is called a stroke volume. So each ventricle is pumping 70 ml of blood and this is what it is called as
the stroke volume. If I multiply this stroke volume by heart rate that is the number of beats per minute.
So what I will get the cardiac output. So what I will get the cardiac output. So I am multiplying 70
with the number of times the heart pumps in a minute which is roughly around 70 to 280.
So whatever volume which I will get this is called as the volume of blood pumped by each ventricle
or the cardiac output. As you can see which is around 5 liter or 5000 ml in case of a healthy individual.
Now body has the ability to alter the stroke volume as well as the heart rate and the cardiac output.
Now talking about the sounds which are associated with the cardiac cycle.
The typical heart sounds. Now during each cardiac cycle there are two prominent sounds
which can be easily heard with the help of stethoscope. The first sound is the love sound which is
associated with the closure of tricuspid and bicuspid valves. When tricuspid and bicuspid valves close
when they do close during ventricular systole in the early part of the ventricular systole in order to prevent any
backflow into the atria and that closure produces this one first sound which is called as lub. Then the second
heart sound is called as dub which is due to the closure of semilunar valves. When the ventricle
undergoes diastole then what happens the pressure decreases and the semilunar valves closes. At this
time that second sound is produced which is called as the dub sound. Now these sounds are of clinical
diagnostic significance. Any deviations from these sounds can be an indication of some kind of disorder.
Now talking about the electrocardiogram or the ECG you must have seen that bip sound
or that graph which coming often associated with the patient on a bed there is a monitor in which this
graph is coming that is called as ECG the electrocardiogram and that graph we will get that
is called as electrocardiogram. So ECG is nothing but a graphical representation of the electrical activity
of heart during a cardiac cycle and it is measured with the help of an instrument in which there are two
leads which are applied on each of the wrists and one lead is applied on the left ankle and with this we
get a standard ECG. For understanding more detailed activity of heart in terms of electrical activity
we use more leads which are applied on the chest. Now each peak in the ECG is identified with a letter
from P to T and that corresponds to a specific electrical activity of the heart. If we will see the graph we
will see there are certain peaks and they each has been represented with particular symbol. Now here
is the relationship between the cardiac cycle and the ECG. Now let us understand this.
When the atrial systole begins how does the atrial systole begins? When the SA node produces that signal
when the SA node produces that electrical impulse and due to production of this electrical impulse
the atrium contract and this is called as atrial depolarization. As you can see here is the atrial
depolarization at the bottom you can see and this P wave which we are getting this is associated with
the contraction of atrium and it comes just before that just before the contraction of atrium
because this wave is actually electrical activity. Once the electrical activity will set in
then the contraction will happen. So it is just before the atria have started contracting. So you can see here
so as the P wave ends the atria is already in the systole you can see the atria are in systole
but the P wave was initiated when the atria were in diastole as you can see here.
Now comes the second phase which is ventricular systole the first phase of that. Now the signal has reached
AV node and from AV node the signal will move into bundle of his and the Purkinsey fiber throughout the
ventricular musculature. So the ventricle will contract and the contraction of ventricle is
a good amount of electrical activity and there you get a peak you can see QRS over here this peak
and obviously this electrical activity precedes what it precedes the contraction of ventricles.
slightly before only it will happen then only the contraction will happen right. So you can see
it is here means it once this peak you can see then the ventricular systole will happen as you can see
and as the ventricle goes into systole atrium has come into diastole you can see and this
part of the ECG is called as QRS complex. Then comes the ventricular systole the second phase.
At this moment the semilunar walls are open and the blood is ejected. So at this time the ventricles have
started relaxing. So beginning of that relaxation. So this will be called as ventricular repolarization.
So this T wave is associated with that and you can see this is T wave ventricular repolarization and after
this you can see the ventriculars have moved into diastole and both are together into joint diastole now.
So then comes the ventricle diastole early part and the ventricle diastole late part. So here
the electromedal activity is not there once again the new cycle will start. So the P wave represents the
electrical excitation of the atria which leads to the contraction of both the atria as you can see in
this sentence which leads to contraction of both the atria. So the P wave is slightly preceding what atrial
systole. The QRS complex represents the depolarization of ventricles means the ventricles
will undergo now contraction and again it is slightly preceding ventricular systole. Then comes
the T wave which is nothing but the return of the ventricles from excited to normal state
which is called as repolarization and it marks the end of systole means now the ventricle will move
into diastole. The ECGs which are obtained from different individuals have roughly the same shape
for a given lead configuration. Any deviation in this shape means there is some kind of abnormality or
disease. For example you can see the ECG of two different individuals here this is the normal one
and here is the ECG which is associated with the person having a myocardial infarction. So this is
nothing but a heart failure. Now further understanding the electrocardiogram or the ECG. So here is the heart,
here is the sinoatrial node, here is the Purkinje fibers or the bundle of his which will be throughout
the ventricular musculature and electrical impulse travels from the sinoatrial node to the walls of
the atria. So in the SA node electrical signal has been generated and where it is moving first it will
move to the atrial walls itself because the atria has to undergo contraction. So this colored part,
which we are seeing in the heart is the area where the electrical activity has reached. So the electrical
activity you can see it is present in the atrial walls and at this moment you are getting this part
of the ECG in the form of this P peak. You can see this is being highlighted over here. So when the electrical
signal is in this part we are getting P. Now moving forward now the electrical signal has reached AV node.
This represents the AV node. Here is the AV node. So the electrical activity is present in this part.
So the impulse reaches the atrioventricular node by a delay of around 0.1 second and at this moment
this part is corresponding to ECG in terms of electrical activity as you can see being highlighted.
Now the signal from AV node is moving through the bundles into the ventricular musculature as you can see.
So you can see the bundles branches are carrying the signal from AV node to the heart apex.
So at this moment you are getting this part in the ECG. The electrical activity is corresponding to this part.
And as the signal spreads into entire ventricular musculature
through all those tiny projecting Purkinsey fibers and the contraction will initiate you will get this major peak.
The QRS. Here comes the QRS peak which is signaling ventricular systole to proceed.
And then here at the end this part is T wave which will signal the repolarization of ventricles.
Now here is a concept checker for you. ECG depicts the depolarization and repolarization processes
during the cardiac cycle. In the ECG of a normal healthy individual one of the following waves is not
represented. Which one is that? The first option is depolarization of atria. Yes, it is there.
That is the P wave. Repolarization of atria. Let us see. The next is the depolarization of ventricle.
It is represented which is the QRS complex. Repolarization of ventricle is also represented
which is the T wave. So it is the repolarization of atria which is not represented instantly.
So the correct answer is the standard ECG. So the correct answer is the B option.
Now the next question. The second heart sound which is dub is associated with the closure of
tricuspid, semilunar valve, bicuspid valve or the tricuspid and bicuspid valves both.
So the second sound which is dub is actually associated with the closure of semilunar valves
which is the pulmonary valve and the aortic valve. So the correct answer is semilunar valves.
So this is what we have for today in this class. We will meet again in the next class.
Bye then. Thank you and take care.
